entry.title: CURP Validation in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Using Business Rules
entry.content:
Introduction: Enhancing Standard Format Checks with Logic-Based Validation

When working with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, ensuring the accuracy of national identifiers is critical â€” especially for country-specific IDs like the Mexican CURP (Clave Ãšnica de Registro de PoblaciÃ³n).

As you may know, Employee Central does offer a standard CURP validation, but it's restricted to format checking. It ensures the CURP is 18 characters and follows the right structure â€” but it does not validate the embedded logic, like date of birth, gender, or state code.

If youâ€™ve struggled with CURP validation in SuccessFactors, or you're looking to make your system more robust and compliant, this solution is simple and scalable.

In this blog, Iâ€™ll share how I implemented a custom Business Rule to take CURP validation a step further â€” by checking that the value entered is not just syntactically correct, but also logically valid based on employee data.

Standard vs. Enhanced Validation

Validation Type       

 Format Check (Standard)

 Logic Check (Custom Rule)

 Length (18 chars)     

 âœ… Yes                  

 âœ… Yes                    

 Character pattern     

 âœ… Yes                  

 âœ… Yes                    

 Date of birth matching

 âŒ No                   

 âœ… Yes                    

 Gender validation     

 âŒ No                   

 âœ… Yes                    

 State code validation 

 âŒ No                   

 âœ… Yes                    

As shown above, the standard validation stops at format. With the Business Rule we extend that to cross-check the CURP content against the employeeâ€™s own data â€” a must-have for maintaining high-quality HR records.

Where This Rule Lives

The rule is configured in the National ID portlet of Employee Central and applies specifically when ID Type = CURP. It triggers during the Hire/Rehire onSave event to ensure validation before saving the record.

Iâ€™ll be sharing the exact configuration, regex pattern, and logical checks I used â€” including how we:

  • Parse CURP values to extract DOB, gender, and state code
  • Compare them with the employeeâ€™s actual personal data
  • Raise friendly error messages when something doesnâ€™t match

Why Bother with Logic Checks?

Hereâ€™s why this matters:

  • Compliance: Inaccurate CURPs can lead to issues with government filings and audits.
  • Data Integrity: Avoid storing incorrect identifiers that may affect integrations or reporting.
  • User Experience: Prevent users from unknowingly entering wrong data that gets saved without warning.

Stay Tuned

In my next section below, Iâ€™ll walk you through:

  • The full business rule logic I used
  • The regex pattern for CURP format validation
  • How to match CURP-encoded DOB with the employeeâ€™s `dateOfBirth` field
  • State code validation using `Picklist` or constant arrays

This is a no-code, configuration-only solution that doesnâ€™t require any external tools â€” just SAP standard functionality and a smart business rule.

Proposed Solution

Business Rule Variants

The logic in CURP involves checking consonants and vowels based on specific characters. To perform this validation, we need to create variants to find these values. Unfortunately, we have to create three different variants for all consonants, since the validations are performed in three different fields. The variants should be created as shown in the example below:

Sample from Demo

Business Rule Conditions

Moving on to the conditions that we must have the rule to perform all validations, below I will break down the explanation according to each part of the CURP logic, this way it will be easier to understand.

You'll notice that in the rule conditions below, I'm already considering "transforming" the name field letters into uppercase, since in ID they are always capitalized. This prevents the name fields from being all filled in with capital letters. If the customer requests the name fields in uppercase, I recommend removing this function from the rule.

 

  1. In the first condition, it is checked whether it is not CURP, the rule is already skipped, in this way we optimize and contribute to the performance of the System.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: First initial letter of the first surname.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first internal vowel of the first surname.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Initial letter of the second last name.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first letter of the first name.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Two digits of the year of birth.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Two digits of the month of birth.

Sample from Demo

 Validation: Two digits of the day of birth.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Gender - Males are assigned the letter H, Females are given the letter M, and others are assigned the letter N.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Tow letters of the State of Birth.

Sample from Demo

For this validation I have added the two letters of each state of birth to the picklist label, to make it simple, and in the rule, we are reading that value inside of the parentheses. Example below of a picklist value.

Sample from Demo

Note: If you have defined the â€œState of Birthâ€ as part of the Biographical Information CSF it will not be possible to retrieve this data, as the rule has a limitation today and does not allow us to access this table.

  1. Validation: The first internal consonant of the first surname.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first internal consonant of the second last name.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first internal consonant of the first name.

Sample from Demo

Additional Resources

As the rule has many validations and extensive variants, I am sharing the rule in a format to be imported but remember that the configuration you have may be a little different from my demo, so after importing you will have to make possible adjustments. Download HERE.

I'm also sharing HERE the link to the guide that explains all the rule functions in case you want to delve deeper into the ones used in the rule.

Conclusion

While SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central provides a good foundation for CURP validation through standard format checks, it's not enough to guarantee data accuracy and compliance in real-world scenarios. By implementing a custom Business Rule, we can go beyond the basics and ensure that CURP values not only follow the expected structure but also make logical sense based on the employeeâ€™s personal information.

This approach is entirely configuration-based, requires no custom development, and is easy to maintain â€” making it a smart enhancement for any organization operating in Mexico.

Validating CURP logic at the point of entry helps avoid downstream errors, ensures alignment with legal requirements, and maintains the integrity of your HR data.

I hope this solution helps you improve your Employee Central setup. Feel free to reach out or comment if youâ€™d like to share how youâ€™ve tackled CURP validation in your own environment.

entry.title: Deploy a React App to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry
entry.content:
Introduction

While working on a recent requirement, we needed to deploy a simple React application to the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Cloud Foundry environment.

In this blog, we will share a step-by-step guide to creating a basic React application and deploying it to the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environment. This tutorial is beginner-friendly and focuses on setting up an application without authentication, making it an ideal starting point before adding advanced features.

Step 1: Create a React App

Creating a new React app using the command:

npx create-react-app myreactapp

This will create a folder named 'myreactapp' with all necessary files and configurations for a basic React app.

Navigating into the project directory using:

cd myreactapp

 

Step 2: Run the React App Locally

I ran the following command in the project directory to make sure the app was working:

npm start

This starts the development server and opens the React app in our default web browser.

Step 3: Build the React App for Production

To prepare our app for deployment, we create a production build using:

npm run build

This command generates a 'build' folder that contains optimized and minified files ready for deployment.

Step 4: Create a manifest.yaml File

Creating a file named 'manifest.yaml' in the project root directory with the following content:

---
applications:
  - name: myreact app
    memory: 128M
    buildpacks:
      - staticfile_buildpack
    path: build

This file defines the application name, memory allocation, buildpack type, and specifies the path to the build directory.

Step 5: Login to Cloud Foundry and Deploy

Login to Cloud Foundry environment using:

cf login

Once logged in, selecting correct organization and space. Then deploy your application using:

cf push

Step 6: Access App from SAP BTP Cockpit

Open SAP BTP Cockpit and navigate to: Cloud Foundry â†’ Spaces â†’ [ Space] â†’ Applications. We select our deployed application and, in the overview tab, find the Application Routes section. Clicking the provided URL opens our React app.

As no authentication is configured, the app will open directly without requiring login.

Project Folder Structure

After creating and building ourReact application, your project directory will contain the following files and folders:

README.md
build
manifest.yaml
node_modules
package-lock.json
package.json
public
src

- `build`: Contains the production-ready version of your app.
- `manifest.yaml`: Deployment configuration for Cloud Foundry.
- `node_modules`: Installed project dependencies.
- `package-lock.json` and `package.json`: Dependency and project metadata.
- `public`: Static files like `index.html`.
- `src`: Your React source code.

In this tutorial, we covered the entire journey of creating a React application locally, building it for production, and deploying it to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry. We now have a working application accessible from the cloud without any authentication requirements.

entry.title: Re: User-id for Concurrent employment
entry.content:
Hi,

Unfortunately, currently it is not possible to generate user id via business rule when you are using concurrent assignment import, you must enter a new user id manually.

If you would like to maintain the consistency of user id, you can go to manage data->sequence, choose the sequence you are using, find the field current, this field is the next user id that is going to be assigned, you can enter this id in your import file so that the user id will follow the same sequence.

Regarding concurrent employment user id generation, you can also refer to the below KBA

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002413277

Best regards,

Elsa

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - New (Measure Based) Model with Account Dimension â€“ Part 2
entry.content:
Introduction

In the previous blog, we discussed how to create the model and save it.

In this blog, we will explore how to populate the data in the model.

Step 1: - Select Data Management under the Workspace section from the tool bar.

Step 2: - Click on the import icon as highlighted in the screenshot below.

Step 3: - Select a data source â€” in my case, Iâ€™m choosing File since Iâ€™ll be importing a file from my system.

Step 4: - Click on 'Select Source File' to import the desired file into the application.

Step 5: - Select the desired file from your system â€” in this case, the Sales Data file.

Step 6: - After selecting the file the system will automatically import data as shown below. If the file contains multiple worksheets choose the appropriate sheet. If applicable enable the 'First Row as Column Headers otherwise manually define the column headers in the configuration stage.

After completing this steps, click on the 'Import' button to proceed.

Step 7: - After clicking the 'Import' button, the imported file will appear in the 'Import Jobs' section. To initiate the configuration process, click on the 'Set Up Import' option.

Step 8: - Prepare Data Stage

The key task involves previewing the data, defining the dimensions and measures, to set column headers, transformation of data, creating calculated columns if needed and build hierarchy.

Click the 'Next' button once all tasks are completed. In this case, since all dimensions and measures are correctly configured with the appropriate data types, you can proceed to the next step.

Step 9: - Map To Facts Stage

Here, we can see that a few source columns are not fully mapped, so drag and drop the 'Month' column into the unmapped section and assign 'Date' as the target.

Most of the columns are already mapped correctly to the respective targets. Though the Mapped section has 'Default Version', on the other hand the source contains an unmapped 'Version' column. To correct this, first we remove the 'Default Version' from the Mapping section and add the 'Version' column from the source.

This is done because the 'version' column contains data specific to 'public.actual'.

After mapping, a pop-up appears to confirm the completion of mapping.

We can see that two columns remain unmapped in the source section and will be mapped in the following stage.

Click on the Next button.

Step 10: - Map Properties Stage

Map the 'Category' column from the source section to Dimension Properties of Version and it is mandatory step that cannot be skipped to specify the version types.

It is mandatory for a Private Account Dimensions to map the 'Hierarchy' column whereas not required for Public Dimensions.

In my case, I am using Private Account Dimensions so I will be mapping the 'Hierarchy' column from the source to the Dimension Property of Account.

After mapping the 'Hierarchy' column, you will see that no source columns remain to be mapped. The Next button will be enabled once all mandatory columns are mapped. Click the â€˜Nextâ€™ button to move to the next stage.

Note: If some source columns are still unmapped, it may be because the target structure doesnâ€™t include them. Itâ€™s not necessary to map every source columnâ€”only the mandatory ones.

Step 11: - Review Import Stage

In the Map to Facts stage, click the Next button to begin the data validation process. The system will automatically validate the data before import, checking for any issues such as missing mandatory field mappings, data type mismatches, structural restrictions, or data quality problems.

If no issues are found during validation, the Run Import button will become enabled, allowing you to proceed. If validation errors are detected, the system will display an error message or a validation summary outlining the issues that need to be addressed. You must correct all identified problems before continuing.

Once validation is successful, click the Run Import button to start importing the data.

Note: It is not mandatory to map all source columnsâ€”only the required fields need to be mapped. Optional columns can remain unmapped if they are not part of the target structure.

When the Run Import process is initiated, a pop-up window appears prompting you to configure the import settings. In this case, no changes are required, so the default settings are used, with the import method set to Update. However, these settings can be modified based on specific requirements, such as choosing a different import method or adjusting validation options. Once the appropriate settings are confirmed, click the Finish button to proceed with the import.

After clicking the Finish button, the status of the import job can be viewed in the Data Management workspace, as shown below.

Step 12: - To preview the data that has been imported into the model structure, navigate to the Model Structure workspace.

Summary

We have created the hybrid model combining both Measure and Account dimensions by understanding how to map the source and target fields along with their properties and then validated the data using Import setting. Then successfully previewed the data using model structure.

Please refer to previous blog - SAP Analytics Cloud - New (Measure Based) Model with Account Dimension - Part 1 .

Thank you for taking the time to read my blogâ€”I hope you found it helpful! If you did, please like, share, and leave a comment.

Stay safe and stay curious!

entry.title: AI-Assisted ERP: Transforming SAP BTP Integration with Faster, Smarter iFlow Development
entry.content:
The Rise of AI in ERP Development

SAP has been the most trusted ERP system for decades in enterprise business, supporting organizations globally with both on-premise and cloud solutions. As companies have grown and interconnected for business, seamless system integration has become essential to keep processes running smoothly.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is now transforming the ERP landscape by helping both functional and technical developers, as well as solution architects, work smarter and faster, automate repetitive tasks, and maintain consistency across projects. AI-assisted ERP is now a realityâ€”something that once seemed like a futuristic concept. It is reshaping the way SAP solutions are designed, built, and delivered.

The Challenges I Face When Building Complex Integration 

As an SAP Integration Suite/CPI consultant, I create complex iFlows and complete integrations between SAP and non-SAP systems. However, building complex iFlows often takes weeks if I do it manually. When creating an iFlow, itâ€™s always the major core components that make it more complicated. Examples include:

  • Complex Structure
  • Message Mapping
  • Value Mapping
  • Groovy Script for intricate, custom logic
  • API Management and API Proxy (Open API Specification)

This process proves time-intensive and prone to inconsistencies, especially for large-scale projects where employees must repeat the same tasks multiple times.

How AI-Assisted ERP Changed the Game for Me

AI use is growing at a considerable speed in all economic sectors, and AI in ERP represents one of the fastest-growing among them. In regard to SAP, we now see SAP AI Core, SAP AI Launchpad, Generative AI Hub, and SAPâ€™s generative AI co-pilot, Joule, in most of SAPâ€™s products and services, including:

  • Build Apps
  • Build Process Automation
  • Build Code
  • Joule Studio 
  • SAP Business Suite
  • etc.

SAP AI is one of the biggest changes on the BTP infrastructure. It allows me to build my own AI pipelines and set my model configurations. The Prompt Manager in SAP Generative AI Hub helps build my custom AI solutions.

Recently, I started working on a product for SAP Integration Suite that accelerates CPI development and integration tasks by 40-50%. I found that if the development of your major core components are automated by AI, it makes the process faster and more reliable. Instead of starting from scratch, AI analyzes Functional Design Specifications (FDS) and generates ready-to-use iFlows complete with message mappings, value mappings, Groovy scripts, and OpenAPI specs.

Where Cerebro SASA Fits In 

Cerebro SASA integrates with SAP Integration Suite and shows you how its powerful AI engine generates iFlows directly from FDS, including all core components and configuration properties. Cerebro SASA can:

  • Generate Message Mapping and Value Mapping
  • Produce an iFlow structure with configuration properties
  • Set OpenAPI Specifications
  • Reduce development effort and timelines
  • Maintain consistency and accuracy between projects

With Cerebro SASA, you can start your development with a 40% head start, adding substantial value to your process.

Cerebro SASA is an SAP Certified Solution that also allows you to carry out a migration from MuleSoft to BTP . You can find Cerebro SASA on SAP Store and Solution hub. It will migrate your MuleSoft APIs to SAP BTP with an AI-powered approach and help you build a faster, scalable, and complex iFlows.

Letâ€™s Talk About What Cerebro SASA Can Do for You

AI-assisted ERP alters how we think about SAP development. By automating integration tasks that once took days or even weeks, AI solutions allow developers to perform faster, smarter, and more reliable integrations.

Cerebro SASA represents one such solution that demonstrates the power of AI in ERP development by helping organizations save time, minimize manual effort, and improve consistency and uniformity between multiple integration projects.

As AI is growing faster then ever, its role in SAP ERP Solutions will only become more vital, making it an essential part of the future of enterprise software development.

Key Benefits of Cerebro SASA

  • Seamless Integration with SAP BTP and Sap Integration Suite and helps integration experts by automating iFlows creation directly from FDS, reducing the manual work.
  • Delivers up to a 40-50% time savings, reducing an organizationâ€™s cost, promoting innovation, speeding up delivery, and adding value for the customer.
  • Generates mappings files and complex Groovy scripts
  • Automates repetitive work and builds highly scalable architecture
  • Connect with cross functional and technical teams smoothly.
  • Secure you Data by deploying to your private Cloud.

The Future of AI-Assisted ERP in SAP

The future of ERP will involve faster integrations and intelligent systems that build themselves while guiding developers to focus on innovation. AI-assisted ERP represents a major step toward this vision, where technology handles the heavy lifting and experts add creativity and strategy.
Cerebro SASA embodies this shift by turning complex SAP BTP integrations into an AI-powered, automated process. Beyond saving time and costs, it creates a new standard for how companies design enterprise software: smarter, scalable, and future-ready.

As AI, tools like Cerebro SASA will help enterprises move from building solutions to co-creating solutions with AI, defining the next era of ERP development.

Discover the Cerebro SASA on the AIFA Labs and explore how it is revolutionizing AI-assisted SAP ERP. Learn how this innovative platform is evolving to simplify integrations, accelerate development, and empower enterprises to co-create smarter, future-ready solutions with AI.

Letâ€™s connect and discuss AI in SAP ERP and enterprise integrations a little further. If you have thoughts, questions, or experiences to share, feel free to drop a comment. Weâ€™d love to hear your perspective!
"GenAI Assisted Content"


Thankyou
Dhruv Kumar
Senior SAP BTP Consultant

entry.title: From Cloud Foundry to Cloud Run : The Journey of Integrating SAP BTP with Google Cloud Platform
entry.content:
Bridging the Clouds Series. Part 1

When I set out to integrate an SAP Fiori App deployed on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry with a backend service on google cloud run, the goal was to securely connect the two platforms without relying on long-lived service account keys. The backend cloud run services- powered by Vertex AI , hosted our trained AI Models and prediction endpoints - making GCP the natural choice for its advanced AI capabilities. I've always believed in practical solutions over overly engineered ones, so my focus was on building a secure, scalable and maintainable integration that just works.

To achieve this, I configured XSUAA for authentication in the Fiori app, set up a destination in SAP BTP to connect to SAP API Hub, and used the API Hub as a secure API Gateway to validate and forward requests. On the GCP side, I enabled Workload Identity Federation, allowing SAP to authenticate with GCP services without exposing credentials. This blog shares my journey, the architecture and the lessons learned while bridging SAP BTP and GCP using modern identity federation techniques.

The Architecture: Bridging Two Worlds

The first step was to visualize how the pieces would fit together. On one side, I had the SAP Fiori app running on Cloud Foundry in SAP BTP, authenticating via XSUAA. On the other hand, a Google Cloud Run service exposing AI Powered endpoints. SAP API Hub Proxy is created for the connecting between the Fiori app and the GCP cloud Run services. The proxy abstracts the connection  setup between Fiori app and the cloud run service.

Process Flow Diagram

 

The Flow diagram illustrates the flow:

  1. SAP Fiori App â†’ Authenticated via XSUAA
  2. Destination in BTP â†’ Points to SAP API Hub
  3. SAP API Hub â†’ Forwards requests to GCP
  4. Google Cloud Run â†’ Hosts the Backend Service (AI -enabled)
  5. Workload Identity Federation â†’ Authenticates SAP with GCP using OIDC

Using this setup you can either hard-code the service account keys in SAP API Hub key value mapping or setup connectivity using identity federation.

(Ironically, my "Practical" solution at first was to use service account key and mark  it as a working model.ğŸ˜Š )

The Implementation : Step by Step

1. Setting up Fiori App & XSUAA Component ğŸ› ï¸

Well, I began building  the Fiori app, I knew it didn't need to be flashy -- just functional. The goal was to create a lightweight UI that could securely communicate with our backend AI services on Google cloud run.. SO, I fired up SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) , my go-to IDE for SAP Development and got to work.

Fiori App Development

The app was a freestyle app with a list report and a details page with a pdf file viewer control -- no fancy charts or animations - just clean and simple. Once the UI was in place, I moved on to the real backbone of the app : authentication and routing.

Configuring XSUAA and Routing

To secure the app, I created an xs-security.json file where I defined the roles and scopes. This will allow to control access at a granular level and ensure only authorized users could trigger backend calls (not just backend calls, even static page calls as wellğŸ¤) .

 

 

 

â€œDefining roles and scopes in xs-security.jsonâ€

Next, I configured the xs-app.json to define the routes. This setup mapped frontend requests to the backend destination configured in SAP BTP. Nothing new in xs-app.json, authenticationtype set to xsuaa to enable xsuaa service to handle the authentication for my app. The destination property in the xs-app is set as the destination created in SAP BTP for my SAP API Hub Proxy.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP API Proxy Destination in SAP BTP

Once the routing was defined, the next step was to set up a destination in SAP BTP that could act as a connector to the SAP API Hub proxy,  which in turn securely forward requests to the google cloud run services. I created a destination in SAP BTP pointing it to the SAP API Hub Proxy Url. The destination was configured as shown below :

 

This destination was then referenced in the xs-app.json route, allowing the Fiori app to securely communicate with the backend service without exposing any credentials.

Deployment to Cloud Foundry

With everything wired up, I deployed the app to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry. Once deployed, the app was visible under HTML5 repository and was able to see the xsuaa service for the deployed app.

 

The destination, htlm5 and xsuaa services were updated as well in instance section.

 

XSUAA:  Backbone of Authentication

If there is one component that truly held this integration together, it is XSUAA. while the app itself was lightweight and the backend powerful, the real connectivity happened in the API Proxy - where identity and trust were established.

In my setup , Azure AD(now Entra ID) was the corporate identity provider. But instead of integrating it directly with the Fiori app, I configured XSUAA as the intermediary. This allowed me to leverage SAP BTP's native security model while still authenticating users against Entra ID.

Once the JWT is issued by XSUAA â€” after validating and re-signing the token received from Entra ID â€” it becomes the key to accessing backend services. The  GCP backend service uses the public key exposed by XSUAA to validate the tokenâ€™s signature, ensuring its authenticity. Once validated, the token is decoded and its claims are inspected â€” particularly the scopes and roles â€” to determine whether the user is authorized to access the requested data.

 

Issues Faced During Implementation

No integration story is complete without a few bumps along the way. 

1. Role Collection Confusion

Even though I had defined roles in xs-security.json, users were getting unauthorized errors. Turns out, I had forgotten to assign the role collection to my user in the BTP cockpit. 

2. Token Forwarding

Initially, the token from XSUAA wasn't being forwarded properly to the backend. I had to explicitly enable token forwarding in the route configuration and ensure in the destination property forwardAuthToken was set as true.

2.Setting Up the SAP API Proxy

When it came to connecting SAP BTP to Google Cloud Run via the SAP API Hub, I explored two distinct paths - one familiar ğŸ˜‰, one modern. Each had its own story, its own lessons.

Option 1: The â€œQuick and Dirtyâ€ Way â€” Service Account Key File

Lets be honest - when you're racing against a deadline, the easiest path is often the one you've walked before. So my first attempt involved using a Google Cloud Service Account key file. I downloaded the JSON key, stored it securely (or so I thought), and configured the SAP API Hub to use it for authentication.

It worked Instantly!!!.

The key file was a "long-lived" credential - and by long lived, I mean a generous 3 months of quietly sitting around, waiting to be leaked. It is static, sensitive and just enough to keep me on edge every time I pushed code.

Still, it was a good starting point - a proof of concept that validated the integration.

How I implemented this Approach ? ğŸ¤”

Step 1 : Creating Key Value Maps in SAP API Hub

To avoid hardcoding sensitive values directly into the API Proxy, I used Key Value Maps (KVMs) - a secure way to store and retrieve configuration data within SAP API Hub.

I created 2 KVM's as shown below one encrypted and another one un-encrypted:

 

The encrypted key value map contains client_id and private_key value from the service account key json file. The un-encrypted key value map contains the URL of the google cloud run service and the service account that is used for authentication.

Below is a sample service account key json file :

 

Step 2 : Using KVM's in Proxy and triggering Cloud Run Service using Policies.

The first thing I needed was a gatekeeper - a policy that would check whether the incoming request from the fiori app included a valid authorization header. if the token was missing or malformed , the proxy would reject the request immediately.

No token? No entry. Simple as thatğŸ›‘ .

Below is a sample SAP API Hub Policy Chart.

 

Looks Fancy right ?ğŸ˜Š. too many icons, policies, to be frank we don't need all. All it takes is just 4 to 5 policies.

Of course, if you're feeling adventurous - or just want to impress your future self - go ahead and include SAP's complete security template -- that's perfect for those who prefer their API's with a side of corporate elegance.

 

Lets see those 4 to 5 Policies needed:

  1. Extract Key value Pairs for un encrypted values 

 

2. Extract Key value Pairs for encrypted values 

  

By now, we have those key values in different variables that can be used across different policies using the request object.

Step 3: Generate a jwt using this service account key.

Using a dedicated generateJWT policy for a service account key a jwt can be created as shown below.

 

Step 4: Exchange jwt with google for access token

Once the jwt is created, exchange it with google for a google access token to trigger a cloud run service as below.

 

 

Hint : you can create a request body directly in this policy or can have another assign message policy to draft a request payload as shown below : 

 

Step 5: Use the access token to trigger GCP Services.

Add the access token as a bearer token in request header and call the google cloud run as shown below:

 

As you can see the request is just modified by adding a header property and this request is moved to backend (GCP).

The access token received in step 4 can be extracted from response using extractvariables policy as shown below:

 

Now, you may ask how the property that hold token values was identified and used in extractvariables policy. Here comes Postman .

Testing with Postman

Before wiring everything into the API Proxy, I needed to be sure I was extracting the right value from Google's token endpoint - specifically , the access token. I knew the response would be in JSON, but I wasn't sure what the exact structure looked like.

So, I did what any developer would do : I fired up Postman.

I manually crafted the JWT, set the headers and made a POST request to Google's OAuth 2.0 token endpoint. Within seconds , Postman returned a clean JSON response. And there it was - the golden key:

  

Option 2: The â€œRightâ€ Way â€” Workload Identity Federation

The right way of authentication using short lived tokens using workload identity federation.

How I implemented this Approach ?ğŸ¤”

It all began with a request from SAP BTP. Nestled inside was an authorization token , proudly bearing the "Bearer" prefix. But before this token could be of any use, it had to shed its formal attire. So, we stripped away the "Bearer" scheme, revealing the raw token underneath - ready for its next challenge. So, a javascript policy was crafted- small but mighty - to extract the raw token by stripping away the "Bearer" scheme as shown below.

 

Under scripts i created a javascript script to do the stripping!.

 

With this token in hand,i approached the google security token service (STS) - a token from a trusted identity provider. And Google , ever the caution gatekeeper, verified the token's origin and issued a shiny new federated token - one step closer to the goal.

lets see how the sts request payload looks like :

 

In the payload, we pass the audience the full path of the workload identity provider created in GCP for SAP BTP. best practice is to create individual provider for each IDP and if these IDP's are identical or similar they can grouped under a single Identity Pool. In subject_token we pass the stripped authorization token from BTP.

Next, lets see the actual request call : 

 

Now, lets extract the federated token from the response : 

 

How did I know the token is available in access_token property? Its the Postman.

 

But the journey wasn't over.

Next, we took this federated token to the IAM Credentials API, requesting an access token for a specific service account - one that had the permissions to invoke a cloud run service and for which mapping is done in workload identity federation. Google, satisfied with the federated token's lineage, handed over the access token .

Before we hit the IAM API, lets prepare the request payload.

 

The audience is your cloud run url . its can be any other services/ resources that supports workload identity federation.

Now, lets hit the IAM API for the token to call our cloud run service.

 

Now armed with this access token, we returned to the original request from BTP. We carefully inserted the token into the Authorization header Then we sent the request onward to Google Cloud.

Lets see how to extract the token from IAM API response and modify the original btp request with new token.

 

How did I know about the property "token"? Postman ğŸ˜‰

 

Now, Modifying the BTP request:

 

And this time? No Rejections. No VPC walls. Just a smooth, secure handshake. Google Cloud verified the access token, recognized the service account, and welcomed the request with open arms.

Disclaimer: Choosing the Right IAM Credentials API Endpoint

When exchanging the federated token for an access token, Google provides 2 similar-looking endpoints:

  • generateAccessToken
  • generateIdToken

generateAccessToken is typically used when you're operating within Google Cloud and need to impersonate a service account to access GCP resources like Cloud Run, Cloud Storage, etc.

generateIdToken , on the other hand, is designed for authenticating external workloads .

Issues Faced & Lessons Learned : The Curious Case of the Missing IP

Just when everything seemed to be working smoothly - Postman tests were green, the SAP API Hub was running smooth and the federated token request was crafted with care - bam ! The call to Google Cloud's Security Token Service (STS) hit a wall. A very well-guarded, VPC - controlled wall.

The error? A cold, unwelcoming rejection from Google Cloud. The reason? The egress IP address of the SAP API Hub proxy wasn't whitelisted in the VPC service Controls. Classic! . Now, If you're working in a corporate network, this is the kind of delightful surprise you should absolutely expect. 

How did I got this details? Its my favourite Google VPC Logs ğŸ˜. See below for the log entry telling me that I violated a policy because my request was originated from this IP address.  So I whitelisted the cadr range in VPC Control firewall rules. 

 

Thankfully, SAP provides documentation that lists the egress IP address used by the SAP API Hub. Once we tracked it down and added the IP to the VPC allowlist, the token request sailed through like it was always meant to.

Reference : https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management-for-neo-environment/region-specific-ip-addresses-available-for-api-management-neo-environment?locale=en-US

Lesson Learned: When integrating across cloud platforms in enterprise environments, always account for network-level controls. 

The Final Piece of the Puzzle - Setting up Workload Identity Federation

Setting up workload Identity federation in Google Cloud is like preparing a backstage pass for your SAP BTP app to access GCP services - securely and with full control.

First, we created an identity pool and an identity provider in GCP, configuring it to trust tokens issued by SAP BTP's XSUAA. Then came the key part : attribute mapping. We mapped attribute.aud to assertion.aud, which corresponds to the name of the fiori app deployed in BTP - the same app for which XSUAA issued the JWT. This mapping is what allows google to recognize  and trust the incoming identity.

To allow the service account to be impersonated, we granted it the necessary roles and bound it to identities matching the mapped attributes. Now, the BTP token could be exchanged for a federated token, and then for an access token tied to the service account.

 

Important: The service account you intend to impersonate must have the roles/iam.workloadIdentityUser role granted on the identity pool. Without this, Google Cloud will not allow the federated identity to impersonate the service account, and the token exchange will fail.

But there was one more twist.

Since the Google access token had to go into the Authorization header to authenticate the request to cloud run, the original jwt from btp would be overwritten. And that JWT still had value - it carried user identity and roles needed for application-level checks.

So, using a policy in SAP API Hub, we copied the original JWT into a custom header( say,x-btp-user-token). This way , the cloud run service could still validate the logged-in user and enforce role-based access - without losing the secure handshake with google.

A little orchestration, a little header juggling - and just like that, I had a secure federated, and role-aware integration .

Final Thoughts

And that's a wrap! From tokens to trust, we've walked through the secure path of integrating SAP BTP with Google Cloud using workload identity federation.

Tried a different approach? Faced a twist I didn't covered? Drop it in the comments - lets learn from each other and keep the collaboration going.

Cheers!!!

entry.title: Re: SAP BAPI_LISTING_CONDITIONS
entry.content:
For information, there is no direct BAPI for VBO2. Given the sensitivity of rebate agreements, here are key questions to clarify:

Functional & Business Impact

  • What specific fields are being changed? (e.g., rate, validity, condition type)
  • Are these changes retroactive or only future-facing?
  • Will these changes trigger recalculations or settlements?

Authorization & Compliance

  • Who approves these changes?
  • Is there an audit trail requirement for modified agreements?
  • Are there any legal or contractual constraints tied to these agreements?

Technical Safeguards

  • Should the Z-program validate existing billing documents before changes?
  • Is there a rollback or backup plan if something goes wrong?
  • Do you want to simulate the changes before applying them?

entry.title: (Legal) Certificate handling for your Business Partners in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hello Master Data community,

I hope you already have seen the impressive Blog Post of my colleague Ahmed Khalifa about Ensuring Business Compliance: Efficient Handling o... - SAP Community

IÂ´d like to take the chance now to let you know that we enabled this great functionality now also in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and S/4HANA from version 2023 onwards.

With that functionality, you can now manage either your legally necessary certificates for the countries you are operating in, or you may want to use them for your business purposes. - There is no limitation on that! ğŸš€

 

Find more information on SAP Help Portal:

Business Partner Certificates | SAP Help Portal

 

To give a sneak peek into the future, we intend to make this feature also available for all countries in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with Release 2602.

 

I hope these insights gave you some inspiration in how you could use that simple but powerful feature on the Business Partner Master Data.

 

See you next time!

 

Kind regards,

Christian Seelinger
